awd_titl_txt: Conference: Proposed Workshop on CPS Rising Stars
awd_abstract_narration:
This project provides a workshop  “Cyber Physical Systems (CPS) Rising Stars” to be held at the University of Virginia.  The purpose of the workshop is to identify and mentor outstanding Ph.D. students and postdocs who are interested in pursuing academic careers in CPS areas. This workshop gives participants a chance to gain insights about navigating the early stages of careers in academia, as well as provide networking opportunities with faculty and peers, opening the door for on-going collaboration and professional support for years to come. The workshop includes a program committee comprised of faculty with extensive background in CPS who will select students for the workshop. One workshop aims to increase representation and diversity in CPS, by encouraging applications from women,underrepresented minorities (URM), and persons with disabilities. A specific effort is also being made to recruit workshop participants who may be at non-R1 schools.

This will be the second CPS Rising Stars Workshop.  This workshop will be modeled after the first including a variety of sessions designed to build a cadre of researchers in CPS and foster future collaborations amongst the students in the field.  The first Rising Star workshop was successful in recruiting a high percentage of URM students.  This workshop will retain this recruiting focus in addition to paying special attention to selection of non-R1 candidates.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

por.por_cntn:
We held the second annual one-day workshop on Cyber Physical Systems (CPS) Rising Stars on May 31, 2023, at the University of Virginia. This workshop recognized outstanding Ph.D. students and postdocs from across the country who have demonstrated a high level of competency in CPS education and research and who wish to continue their work in CPS, primarily in Academia. The workshop was very successful with 34 award winners out of 117 applications from 53 different Universities and from 8 different department types. Twenty-four of the CPS Rising Stars were from underrepresented minorities. Attendees indicated the very high value of the workshop. This workshop gave participants a chance to gain insights regarding applying for faculty positions, navigating the early stages of careers in academia, and provided networking opportunities with faculty and peers, opening the door for ongoing collaboration and professional support for years to come. 

One of the main goals of this workshop was to increase representation and diversity in CPS, especially encouraging applications from the following underrepresented groups in science and engineering as identified by the NSF: women, persons with disability, and/or three racial and ethnic groups - Hispanic or Latino, Blacks or African Americans, and American Indians or Alaska Natives.  A specific effort was made to advertise the workshop to HBCUs and minority serving institutions. We found that many HBCUs do not even have PhD programs or when they do, they are not supporting PhDs in CPS. Nevertheless, we have created a curated list of potential non R1 schools that can be used and expanded in future years.  We aimed to select as many highly qualified diversity applicants to attend the workshop as possible. We were successful in choosing 24 of the 34 selectees from underrepresented groups, but only 1 from non R1 schools due to a scarcity of such applications.

More details about the workshop organizaton, inlcuding the list of selected rising stars, can be found at the workshop website: 

https://risingstars.linklab.virginia.edu/2023/

 

 


Last Modified: 04/02/2024
Modified by: Lu Feng
